^In the year of our Lord 1655, the Polish king disbanded the Sejm -- that is, the Parliament -- and proclaimed himself Czar in the same fashion as the sovereign of Moscow. But the treasonous gentry could not let this stand, and soon revolt had gripped all the lands of Great Poland and Lithuania, Rusyn and Ukraine. In an attempt to stamp out the growing rebellion, the king hired German Landsknechts as mercenaries. ^^ Before long the entire Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth was consumed by the fires of war, like so much dry kindling. As for Jan Kasimir, the would-be czar, upon losing the loyalty of the people and the gentry, he abdicated the throne and fled, accompanied by his latest commander, a low-born warlord known as {playername}. At the border between Masovia and Prussia, they were ambushed by a large group of bandits, a common enough danger in those days. The king and his companions were killed, and no one has ever discovered where their remains lie hidden. ^^ Zenon Petretsky, "A Short History of the Polish Commonwealth" (1855).^^^

^In the year of our Lord 1656, the Polish king, executing the Hetman of the Crown {playername} for treason, disbanded the Sejm - that is, the gentry Parliament - and proclaimed himself Tsar in the same fashion as the sovereign of Moscow. But the treasonous gentry could not let this act stand, and thus came the revolts in the lands of Great Poland, Lithuania, Rusyn and Ukrainian lands, which the king sought to pacify with German Landsknechts. Before long, the entire Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth burned in the fires of war like so much dry kindling. Jan Kasimir himself fled, upon losing the loyalty of the people and the gentry, abdicating the throne. Along the border between Masovia and Prussia, he was ambushed by a large group of bandits, one of many such bands that plagued the land in those days. The king and his companions were killed, and no one has ever discovered where their remains lie hidden. ^^ Zenon Petretsky, "A Short History of the Polish Commonwealth", 1855.^

In the year of our Lord 1656, the mighty king and the great warlord {playername} were cut down by an assassin's dagger. Sic transit gloria mundi -- thus passes the glory of the world. ^^ "The Tale of the Dreadful Years", Saint Pafnuty of Novgorod

You shall sooner count all the leaves on a tree than all the enemies I have slain. Were my hair as numerous as the foes I've brought down by my own hand, the barbers of Lukovo would make a fortune trimming my forelock! The devil take me if I lie...

In olden times, we had but one defeat for every ten victories, and the whole world was awed by our valor. Yet now we suffer nothing but defeat, and we are betrayed not only by lone rascals but by entire provinces! God have mercy on our homeland!

I have a mighty thirst to taste Swedish meat once more, like a wolf thirsting for lamb! Oh, aren't they scoundrels! Fleas must've gotten into their tiny stockings and bitten their legs, so they can't sit still at home and keep intruding on lands which are not theirs...
I have bled the Swedes quite a bit with these hands, and shall bleed them more yet. Few soldiers remain of those who had seen me under Putsk and Trcziana, but those who survive remember me well.

I am the old hero of Zbarazh... With this very hand I laid the axe on Burlai, the greatest hetman after Hmelnitski himself. Whosoever has not heard of Zagloba must have been under a rock during all the first Cossack War, or stuffed up his ears, or who knows what. I do hope that such a worthy man as you was not hiding under a rock, right?

It is time for my old bones to rest. I had best lay by the hearth, eat my curds with sour-cream, walk through the garden and pick apples, oversee the reapers' work and pat the girlies on the back. And perhaps even my foes will leave me be, for the Swede and the Cossack both know how heavy my hand can be. And God be willing, my name shall be celebrated by my brothers as well as it is feared by my enemies.

It is past time for me to rest, though the homeland is in peril and the foe tramples our lands. And here I am, bringing battle to the enemy, together with you, all in the name of our Motherland which nurtured us all. Whosoever shall not rise to defend her today, to deliver her from the scourge, is no son of the Motherland, but ungrateful stepchild unworthy of her love.

Even as I grow old, and God be willing, even as I lay dying, I shall cry out "Death to the Swedes, brothers! Forward!" Let us swear to grasp our blades steadfastly until we banish the enemy from our homeland!

Even the lion roars before a fight to fill himself with anger... As for great warriors, each has a manner of his own. Hannibal, they say, played the dice, Scipion of Africa read poems, Colonel Konetspolski, our father, loved to talk of girls, and as for me -- I must rest before battle, and drink a merry cup or two with my friends.

As old men say, the evil spirits dare not approach drinks, so you can drink everywhere and be safe. But beware food, and moreso of soup. There was a time, in Crimea, when I was in bondage. The Tatar mullahs -- that be priests in our tongue -- they could prepare lamb with garlic so good that you taste it once, and the very next second you're ready to forget your faith and follow their rascal prophet.
I made my way into the favor of the Crimean Khan himself, for discerning a plot to take his life while I was in my captivity. And our gracious King Jan Kasimir loves me dearly as well.

After every such sally, after we cut down five or ten thousand bandits, I can hear Hmelnitski banging his head on the wall, and saying: "That, I be damned, must be the work of that hellspawn Zagloba!" Well, after peace came to the Zborov, the Khan himself looked at me in awe, and asked me to leave a portrait, which he wanted to send as a souvenir to the Turkish Sultan.

I swear by God, this is an omen! We shall crush those villains, the Germans, the stocking-legged fish-eaters, and all the other lice-ridden and beardy scum who walk in sheepskin coats in winter and ride in sledges! We shall give them merry hell, and send them running for their lives. All whoever escapes we'll hunt down like dogs! Raise your hand and strike them down, all of you to whom the Motherland and your very honor are dear!

I know what rank means, and I can rise to any rank, you mark my words! A second Zbarazh shall I make here, a second Zbarazh! Radziwill will choke, and so will the Swedes, before any of them can swallow me! I even dare Khovansky to strike us! I would have buried him so well his remains would not be found until the Second Coming. Let them all come! Let them try!

All worthy men like to drink. Only traitors who nurse ill thoughts of their Motherland fear wine, lest they become drunk and betray themselves. Radziwill drinks birch-juice, but after his death he shall drink tar! Verily so shall it be, God help me!

My hands are full, but what can I do!? No one in our Commonwealth can use their wits, so old Zagloba must make double use of his one, while he still lives! And the worst part is that I still have no chancellery.

It is my belief that the misfortunes of our Motherland are all due to debauchery, unruliness and excesses -- yes I say excesses -- which devour us like the plague. Yet first of all, the heretics are to blame, for they ridicule the true faith, reviling our mistress who ought to strike them down with her righteous anger...
These times are such that whosoever holds the blade is right! And what right does the Swede and all our enemies then have, to ravage the lands of the Polish Commonwealth?

We had to send Khovansky a letter, demanding that he swiftly take himself to hell, lest we smoke him out of all our towns and strongholds. The Muscovites now lay still in Lithuania, and take no fortresses, but Zolotarenko's Cossacks plunder the people, roam about Lithuania in gangs of one or even two thousand blades. Let Khovansky pacify them, or we shall have to take the matter in our own hands.

I want to speak to our chosen one, our good lord, to comfort him in his misery -- to let him know that there still are people who have not left him, that there still are hearts and blades ready to battle at the mere wave of his hand. Let our father, our lord of noble Jagiellon blood, who is forced to live the life of a wanderer, have at least this small remedy.
Let us drink to the Huns' death, that they may eat our bread no more! Let them instead eat fir cones in Sweden!

Pity that old eyes see nothing in the dark. Alas, nothing can be done! Once it gets dark, I cannot wield a blade! In the day, in the light, this old man still loves to go to the battlefield. Give me Swedes -- and only the strong ones -- but only at noon!

I tell you, were one sin forgiven for every infidel this old hand sent to hell, I would have been sanctified by now -- and you would have to fast on my birthday, or perhaps I would even rise up into the heavens on a chariot of fire.

Oh you men, lowly men, how vain you are! Lord Jesus Christ, had you given me as many thousand thaler as there are claimants to the Polish crown, perhaps even I would have claimed it... What, do they think I am worse than they? Let them burst of their vain arrogance...

The chronicles would have said otherwise, but there is no luck in this world for me... Such is the gratitude of men... Oh well, it is not the first time... Others sit in warm, high places, becoming as cluttered with fat as badgers, but you old man, you shall ride your wretched nag until the end of time... Damn gratitude! We all go down, so let me at least serve my homeland for a little while before I lay myself down for good.

The German, the French, the British or the black-faced Spaniards, all of them grab the knife at first sight, but the Pole, patient by nature, shall endure many hardships, shall let the Swedes mock him for a long time, and then, when he cannot bear it any longer, he shall punch the Swede's face so hard that he will flip over backwards three times...
There remain bold youths in the Polish Commonwealth -- and while they still live and breathe, the Commonwealth shall never perish.
No trouble lasts forever. It all comes an end, or we shall be ruled by the devil and not our Lord Jesus, whose mercies are boundless.
The sooner we crush the Swedes, the better. Damn them! Let them give over Lettland, and pay a larger ransom and -- oh all right, all right, let him go back in one piece.

Oh Lord my God, have we committed a grave sin against our king? He who has been, is, and shall ever be our father, for he is heir to the house of Jagiellon! Such a king who was abandoned by those traitors who would lay in bed with the foreign devils. Ach, our lot is well earned...

Let Holy Mary Mother of God keep us, like that Colonel who was blasted along with his horse, and flew over the river Visla -- and found himself alive and well. Stood up and ran to a priest, all before lunchtime! Let us not panic! God willing, we shall pluck all foes like crayfish from their holes...

I was the king's most trusted confidant; choosing good elders is second nature to me, and I have given titles freely left and right. Many are indebted to my mercies, and when I entered into a place, all the senators there would bow down low, in good Cossack fashion.
More than once have I fought in contests before the king, and he always loved to watch my work. Even the Marshal would squirm and shut his eyes tight!
I am too old to storm strongholds... much better is an open fight in the field.

Many think of what awaits us. How many fights, how many defeats... How many tears? How much blood shall be shed? How many times shall our lives hang by a thread? And many fall to doubt, many sin in their hearts against God's mercy and the Holy Mother of God... Yet to you I speak -- do you know what awaits our enemies? Death. You know what awaits us? Victory!

A long time ago, in the lands of the polyan tribe, a piece of black iron fell from the sky, and was taken by their soothsayers. Where it fell they set up a pagan temple, worshipping the celestial gift as if it were bestowed upon them by the thunder-god Perun. Soon a large town, Kiev, rose up not far away. The soothsayers understood that this "sky iron" would protect their lands. Prince Svyatoslav Igorevich seized it from the soothsayers, and ordered a Black Mace forged from the iron. With this Black Mace, he won countless victories -- routed the Khazars and Bulgars, even threatened the all-powerful Romei of Byzantium. ^Nowadays there is a belief amongst the soldiers of the Prince, and the Cossack Starshinas, that he who holds the Black Mace shall have power for all the lands "as nigh as a three month journey from the city of Kiev". The soothsayers took their revenge on Prince Svyatoslav, as they once had on prince Oleg. They stole the mace while the prince was on one of his marches, and thereupon Svyatoslav died. The Black Mace fell into the hands of the princes of the house of Oleg. But thereafter its trail runs cold, and no one knows where it has landed.

Universis et singulis, praesentibus et futuris -- to all and each, now and in the future. The Cossacks of Ukraine! By God's will, and your wisdom, am I appointed to guard the liberties of the lands of Ukraine. The people of Ukraine may at last breathe easily, as masters of their lands. Yet the Polish eagle is restless in its lust for prey. The gentry, along with their King, look only to how they might return the yoke to your necks, my brother Cossacks. Yet that shall not come to pass! We shall not wait, lest we become the conquered once more! Nay, we shall set out with a vast militia, against the enemy -- and bring his house to ruin! In alliance with marksman regiments, we shall crush the Polish Commonwealth and subdue its lands for our Cossack nation. Vae victis -- woe to the conquered ones. ^Kiev. Hetman of the Zaporozhian Host and all Ukraine, the lord of Valash, Bogdan Hmelnitski.
